If I add a BlockMarkdown and a BlockRadioGroup with a BlockRadioButton in the admin, save and reopen the form then the BlockRadioButtonInline form is also added to the BlockMarkdownInline. I created a test project to reproduce the behavior: https://github.com/tobiase/django_nested_admin_test **Create form** **Update form** `models.py` ```python class BlockMarkdown(Block): value = models.TextField(verbose_name=_("Value")) class Block(PolymorphicModel): survey_step = models.ForeignKey("survey.SurveyStep", models.CASCADE) class BlockRadioGroup(Block): label = models.CharField(verbose_name=_("Label"), max_length=255) class BlockRadioButton(models.Model): radio_group = models.ForeignKey(Block, models.CASCADE) label = models.CharField(verbose_name=_("Label"), max_length=255) ``` `admin.py` ```python class BlockRadioButtonInline(nested_admin.NestedTabularInline): model = BlockRadioButton class BlockInline(nested_admin.NestedStackedPolymorphicInline): model = Block class BlockMarkdownInline(nested_admin.NestedStackedPolymorphicInline.Child): model = BlockMarkdown class BlockRadioGroupInline(nested_admin.NestedStackedPolymorphicInline.Child): model = BlockRadioGroup inlines = [BlockRadioButtonInline] child_inlines = ( BlockMarkdownInline, BlockRadioGroupInline, ) ``` In any case this works different than I expected it to. items.body:
I'm running:

```
Django==3.0.2
django-grappelli==2.14.1
django-nested-admin==3.2.4
```

Admin code looks like this:
```
class AInline(nested_admin.NestedStackedInline):
    model = A
    sortable_field_name = "name"
    extra = 0


class Bnline(nested_admin.NestedStackedInline):
    model = B
    inlines = [A]
    sortable_field_name = "name"
    extra = 0


class CAdmin(nested_admin.NestedModelAdmin):
    inlines = [B]
```

When I click on the delete button, it changes the values of the `name` field on each of the nested items to ascending integers. Stepping through the JS debugger, I narrowed it down to the `sortable.js:updatePositions()` function. I was able to work-around by removing the `sortable_field_name` from the inlines.

Thanks for all your work on this great library! Keep it up! :)

items.title: Control nested display to not use popups
items.body:
I'm fairly new to Django and I have a simple model that I'm having trouble controlling the admin interface on.  I want a user to be able to edit the content on a page.  To support that, I have a PageContent model, which can have multiple PageSection models, each of which can have multiple PageParagraph models.  Since I have different types of pages that each can include a PageContent, I used a OneToOneField for any page model type that will contain a PageContent.

#### models.py
```
class PageContent(models.Model):
    pass

class PageSection(models.Model):
    heading = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    content = models.ForeignKey(PageContent, on_delete=models.CASCADE)

class PageParagraph(models.Model):
    paragraph = models.TextField()
    section = models.ForeignKey(PageSection, on_delete=models.CASCADE)

class PageTypeOne(models.Model):
    ...
    content = models.OneToOneField(PageContent, on_delete=models.CASCADE)
```
#### admin.py
```
class PageParagraphInline(nested_admin.NestedStackedInline):
    model = PageParagraph

class PageSectionInline(nested_admin.NestedStackedInline):
    model = PageSection
    inlines = [PageParagraphInline]

class PageContentInline(nested_admin.NestedStackedInline):
    model = PageContent
    inlines = [PageSectionInline]

class PageTypeOneAdmin(nested_admin.NestedModelAdmin):
    pass

admin.site.register(PageTypeOne, PageTypeOneAdmin)
```
What I would like to get is something like [this](https://www.frankiedintino.com/static/misc/nested-admin-issue-135.png), where you can see the editable fields for each nested layer from the top level ModelAdmin.

Instead, I get a dropdown box and a + symbol that pops up the admin interface for the PageContent model in a separate window.
![screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24919920/78165245-0976b380-7419-11ea-99eb-5916726f5963.png)

Is there a way to force the nested models to show up in the same page rather than on a popup?

Thanks!

items.title: Better documentation on how to install in Django 3.0
items.body:
The documentation states that in order to include your app, one needs to add the following to `urls.py`:
```python
# urls.py

urlpatterns = patterns('',
    # ...
    url(r'^nested_admin/', include('nested_admin.urls')),
)
```
This does not work  in Django 3 for the following reasons:
 - The variable urlpatterns is a list of paths by default
 - neither `url` nor `include` are defined

Also, one needs to define a STATIC_ROOT in order to be able to execute `$ python manage.py collectstatic` as requested in the [documentation](https://django-nested-admin.readthedocs.io/en/latest/quickstart.html) . Even if the error message is pretty helpful in this case, it would still be nice to mention it somewhere.

Because personally, I do not need all the great features that you have over other nested solutions, I will be using something simpler which only needs installing as a django application (so no pressure from my side to do anything).

Other Django 3 beginners, however, might be thankful if you could find the time to include better documentation on how to install your app.

items.title: Drop support for python 3.4
items.body:
Python 3.4 won't be supported past March 2019. It has reached end of life - see https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0429/

So it's probably prudent to drop this in travis. Tangentially related to #133 as that's where I discovered it.

items.title: Option to repeat headers when using inline
items.body:
When you're using a tabularinline and there are several items it will look something like this. 

```
- Header
- Item
    - inline
    - inline
    - inline
- Item
    - inline
    - inline
    - inline
- Item
    - inline
    - inline
```

The issue is that when you scroll down you won't be able to see the header any longer for the last item if there are many. So readability becomes an issue. I would suggest that there is at least an option to repeat the header for each item, or that this becomes the default option. This makes it a lot more readable. 

Let me know what you think.

items.title: Prepopulate fields from FK field in nested situation
items.body:
Let's say that we've got a FK field and that we need to copy some of these values from the FK parent. When you click add another there is no easy way of making this happen, all the fields will turn up blank. 

I think there should be a built-in way of defining what fields you'd like to pre-fill and when you click `add another` those fields should be prefilled from the FK parent.

items.title: Can't use the tag extrastyles in your own template
items.body:
If you're using your own template in admin and using `{% block extrastyles %}` to add some extra styles and overwrite django-nested-admin styles that will fail because the styling for extrastyles comes before the nested admin styles. 

Ideally the styling from nested admin should come before that styling block.

items.title: First nested item does not expand in a deeply nested model structure using Grapelli
items.body:
I'm having trouble with the nested admin when trying to expand (mouse-click) the first collapsed sub-item of a NestedStackedInline item using the grappelli interface: It won't expand. When I click "add another", the newly added item can be expanded, but the first item still can't be expanded. This is highly unfortunate, because when I try to save the entire nested model (NestedModelAdmin) like this, my field validation raises numerous errors as it tries to save a some model without any data.

I am using a rather deeply nested structure with three NestedStackedInline items below the superior NestedModelAdmin, each (except the last) representing a 1:m relation: NestedModelAdmin - NestedStackedInline1 - NestedStackedInline2 - NestedStackedInline3. Strangely, the issue in the admin only occurs when trying to expand an item belonging to either NestedStackedInline2 or NestedStackedInline3 - no problem with NestedStackedInline1. And to complicate things further, the issue only occurs for the second/third/... item of NestedStackedInline1; for the first one, everything works fine.

What I have further observed is that, when an item can not be expanded and I click it several times, sometimes it appears as if it tries to expand (for a few microseconds) but then immediately it collapses again.

On the frontend, the HTML code only differs with respect to the order of the css classes that are assigned to the <div> elements containing the collapsed NestedstackedInline. This one can not be expanded (div classes do not change):

However, as far as I know the order of css class attributes can be completely arbitrary?

items.title: post_save() signal on parent not working as expected
items.body:
To my understanding models are saved parent first

- ParentModel
   - ChildModel
      - GrandchildModel
         - Field (new value)

So when saving, ParentModel is saved first and GrandchildModel (with new value in Field) is saved last.

The problem is that I need to get the new values in the **ParentModel** `post_save()` signal, but that does not work since the _new value_ is not saved yet. Defining a `post_save()` on GrandchildModel is not sufficient since there are potentially many nested models whose changes need to be tracked, so the most efficient way is to look for changes in ParentModel.

I hope there is a way to achieve that...

items.title: Overriding save_formset?
min_num conflicts with deletions of inlines
items.body:
Hopefully I can explain this clearly:

On a nested admin page set up like this

ParentAdmin
-- inline ChildAdmin
---- inline GrandChildAdmin

where Child is a many to many of Parent, and GrandChild is a many to many of Child,

that has min_num = 1 on GrandChildAdmin.

In this case, GrandChildAdmin.min_num = 1 was added *after* existing data was populated. Some of the existing data will have Child records that have no GrandChildren.

User tries to edit a Parent record that has Child records with no GrandChildren and delete a Child record with no GrandChildren. On save, the delete fails, with the error message This Field Is Required on GrandChildren.

If user adds a GrandChild just to be able to delete the Child, this also errors on save because the Child record is deleted first, then the insert into the Many To Many through table fails with a foreign key violation.

Can we ignore min_num validation on deletes?

items.title: Incompatible with django-autocomplete-light
items.body:
This package works wonder (thanks) by itself but it does things differently from the default django admin site, it becomes a bit of a pain when paired with [django-autocomplete-light](https://github.com/yourlabs/django-autocomplete-light).

Note that in addition of the issues below, yourlabs/django-autocomplete-light#917 will need to be fixed too in order to achieve full compatibility.

### Issue 1: Inserting the row before renaming the attributes

Django [updates the attributes](https://github.com/django/django/blob/94cd8efc50c717cd00244f4b2233f971a53b205e/django/contrib/admin/static/admin/js/inlines.js#L82) before [inserting the row](https://github.com/django/django/blob/94cd8efc50c717cd00244f4b2233f971a53b205e/django/contrib/admin/static/admin/js/inlines.js#L85) but nested admin [inserts the row](https://github.com/theatlantic/django-nested-admin/blob/fdccdce079fc2f4f48dabf950e6fb9c90d488152/nested_admin/static/nested_admin/src/nested-admin/jquery.djangoformset.js#L245) before [updating the attributes](https://github.com/theatlantic/django-nested-admin/blob/fdccdce079fc2f4f48dabf950e6fb9c90d488152/nested_admin/static/nested_admin/src/nested-admin/jquery.djangoformset.js#L252-L254) which means when initializing an item on [DOMNodeInserted](https://github.com/yourlabs/django-autocomplete-light/blob/622b10757bbd0117c6e4b93e6afc68e124e6b764/src/dal/static/autocomplete_light/autocomplete.init.js#L53-L55), it will fail because not all the element is ready.

FWIW, I don't think it would be possible to initialise on the `formset:added` event because this is supposed to work for regular field for which `formset:added` will never be called.

### Issue 2: Not updating the attributes on all elements

Nested admin only replace the attributes on a [subset of elements](https://github.com/theatlantic/django-nested-admin/blob/1dba49177e32f2fddd35f191cc836bd88114ac49/nested_admin/static/nested_admin/src/nested-admin/utils.js#L22) while Django replace the attributes on [every elements](https://github.com/django/django/blob/94cd8efc50c717cd00244f4b2233f971a53b205e/django/contrib/admin/static/admin/js/inlines.js#L81-L82). However autocomplete light [uses a div](https://github.com/yourlabs/django-autocomplete-light/blob/08d69f0938836d511e1866f77286237c6e4f897b/src/dal/widgets.py#L90-L92) for its field configuration and it doesn't get processed.

items.title: Problems with django-tabbed-admin
items.body:
The Nested admin inline not allowed to add new lines is drawn correctly.

Example:
**settings.py**
```
INSTALLED_APPS = [
    'django.contrib.admin',
    'django.contrib.auth',
    'django.contrib.contenttypes',
    'django.contrib.sessions',
    'django.contrib.messages',
    'django.contrib.staticfiles',
    'tabbed_admin',
    'nested_admin',
    'smart_selects',
]

```
**urls.py**
```
from django.conf.urls import url
from django.contrib import admin
from django.conf.urls import include

urlpatterns = [
    url(r'^nested_admin/', include('nested_admin.urls')),
    url(r'^admin/', admin.site.urls),
    url(r'^chaining/', include('smart_selects.urls')),
]
```
**models.py**
```
from smart_selects.db_fields import ChainedForeignKey 

class Continent(models.Model):
    name = models.CharField(max_length=255)

    def __unicode__(self):
        return self.name


class Country(models.Model):
    continent = models.ForeignKey(Continent)
    name = models.CharField(max_length=255)

    def __unicode__(self):
        return self.name


class TableOfContents(models.Model):
    tabla = models.CharField(max_length=200)
    fecha = models.DateTimeField('Fecha de publicacion')

    def __unicode__(self):
        return self.tabla


class TocSection(models.Model):
    tabla = models.ForeignKey(TableOfContents)
    seccion = models.CharField(max_length=200)
    position = models.IntegerField()

    def __unicode__(self):
        return self.seccion

class TocArticle(models.Model):
    section = models.ForeignKey(TocSection)
    position = models.IntegerField()
    continent = models.ForeignKey(Continent, blank=True, null=True)
    country = ChainedForeignKey(Country, chained_field="continent",chained_model_field="continent", 
		show_all=False, auto_choose=True, sort=True, blank=True, null=True)
    city = models.CharField(max_length=50, default='Olvera')
    street = models.CharField(max_length=100, default='Pozo')

    def __unicode__(self):
        return self.city
```
**admin.py**
```
from django.contrib import admin

# An example admin.py for a Table of Contents app

from django.contrib import admin
import nested_admin
from tabbed_admin import TabbedModelAdmin

from .models import *

class TocArticleInline(nested_admin.NestedTabularInline):
    model = TocArticle
    sortable_field_name = "position"
    extra = 0

class TocSectionInline(nested_admin.NestedTabularInline):
    model = TocSection
    # sortable_field_name = "position"
    extra = 0
    inlines = [TocArticleInline]
    classes = ('collapse',)

class TableOfContentsAdmin(TabbedModelAdmin, nested_admin.NestedModelAdmin): 
    tab_info = (('Datos varios', {'fields': ('fecha', 'tabla',)}),)
    tab_secciones = (TocSectionInline, ) 
    tabs = [
        ('Datos Generales', tab_info),
        ('Secciones', tab_secciones),
    ]
    #inlines = [TocSectionInline, ]

admin.site.register(TableOfContents, TableOfContentsAdmin)
admin.site.register(Continent)
admin.site.register(Country)
```

items.title: OPTIONS[`string_if_invalid`] in settings.TEMPLATES breaks functionality
items.body:
Wanting to have nested inlines in the admin (without sorting), I tried the app with a string value for `OPTIONS['string_if_invalid']` in `settings.TEMPLATES`. I encountered two errors:

- Without assigning a `sortable_field_name` to the inline, a `KeyError` was raised, because the `string_if_invalid` value is assumed to be a field of the `ModelForm` used, which was not the case.

- I therefore set `sortable_field_name` to `None` (assuming it would disable sorting). In this case, the `string_if_invalid` value was displayed in the HTML and the formset was not working at all.

Without setting `string_if_invalid'`, the app works, but still I think this is not an expected behavior, unless `sortable_field_name` is required, which I did not see mentioned in the docs (perhaps I missed it?).

items.title: Suit works and looks OK - unless using tabs
items.body:
Hi.
First of all - this is the first package that works on every django admin system i need - so really thanks for that. But for Django Suit there is a small issue. Suit has a features to use tabs and this does not work with this package.

As it states in documentation http://django-suit.readthedocs.io/en/develop/form_tabs.html#example classes for tabs are defined in property "suit_classes"

Problem is that HTML for nesting/admin/inlines - files stacked.html and tabular.html has no class "suit_classes".

{{ inline_admin_formset.opts.suit_classes }}

First div in Suit stacked
`<div class="inline-group {{ inline_admin_formset.opts.suit_classes }}" id="{{ inline_admin_formset.formset.prefix }}-group">`

First div in django-nested-admin stacked
`<div class="inline-group group djn-group djn-stacked{% if is_nested %} djn-group-nested{% else %} djn-group-root{% endif %}"`

I've seen there are some conditionals "ifsuit", "ifnosuit" in "common" view for standard admin and suit. But for grappelli there are different views. I did not make pull request with a fix because i don't know how you would like to organize this.

I hope my explanation is clear.

items.title: Is it possible to mix order of inlines?
items.body:
I have models:
```
# models.py

class ParagraphTable(Paragraph):
    """Paragraph is just a model with GenericForeignKey field"""
    table = TableField()


class ParagraphImages(Paragraph):
    style = models.CharField(default='', max_length=255)


class ImageItem(models.Model):
    file = models.ImageField(upload_to='paragraph/images/%Y/%m/%d')
    parent = models.ForeignKey(ParagraphImages, on_delete=models.CASCADE)


class Node(models.Model):
    title = models.CharField(default='', max_length=255)
```

and admin:

```
# admin.py

class ImageInline(nested.NestedStackedInline):
    model = ImageItem
    extra = 0


class ParagrpaphImagesInline(nested.NestedGenericStackedInline):
    model = ParagrpaphImages
    sortable_field_name = 'order_weight'
    extra = 0
    inlines = [ImageInline]


class ParagraphTableInline(nested.NestedGenericStackedInline):
    model = ParagraphTable
    sortable_field_name = 'order_weight'
    extra = 0


class NodeAdmin(nested.NestedModelAdmin):
    inlines = [ImageStorageInline, ParagraphTableInline]
    weight_field_name = 'order_weight'

```

All works like a charm. Drag and drop support allows me sort my inlines under their parents.
So, I can change sort order between inlines of same type.

But UI allow drag and drop one of inlines under another type. In my case, I can drag ParagraphImages and drop among ParagraphTables. Actually, it is what I really need. But on save I'm getting "MultiValueDictKeyError" or "ManagementForm data is missing or has been tampered with".

Actually, I wrote same app for myself, but I didn't create nested feature and then I found this awesome package. And I solved the problem in a dummy-way, I just reorder back all inlines before save, and reorder on page load.

So, the question: Is it possible to use merged inlines sorted between their types?

===
The purpose of that behaivior is create "polymorphic" content types, there admin can add any inline in any order to build content page (like here: https://www.drupal.org/project/paragraphs)

items.title: Grappelli autocomplete field in nested inline got initialized twice if parent inline has autocomplete field with same name
items.body:
As described, consider the case below:

```
class ChildInline(NestedStackedInline):
    fields = ('name', 'category')
    raw_id_fields = ('category',)
    autocomplete_lookup_fields = {'fk': ('category',)}

class ParentInline(NestedStackedInline):
    fields = ('name', 'category')
    inlines = (ChildInline,)
    raw_id_fields = ('category',)
    autocomplete_lookup_fields = {'fk': ('category',)}
```

the autocomplete field 'category' in ChildInline will be initialized twice, so that two input box will appear.
in `DJNesting.initAutocompleteFields`,  `$('#' + prefix + '-group > .djn-items > *:not(.djn-empty-form)')
        .find('input[name^="' + prefix + '"][name$="-' + this + '"]')` will also find input in child inline with the same name.
currently, removing the 'category' field from autocomplete_loopup_fields in ChildInline seems ok.

items.title: Don't require "nested_admin" to precede "django.contrib.admin" in INSTALLED_APPS
items.body:
There is currently a bug where nested admin's monkey patching only works if `"nested_admin"` precedes `"django.contrib.admin"` in `INSTALLED_APPS`. There is no reason why the order of `INSTALLED_APPS` should matter, so investigate why this is a problem and get rid of this requirement.

This issue was originally discovered in #46

items.title: Add ability to specify classes on admin inline fields (to collapse)
items.body:
Hi !

This commit https://github.com/django/django/commit/5399ccc0f4257676981ef7937ea84be36f7058a6 (applied to Django 1.10) allows to collapse inlines exactly like regular formsets, just by adding `classes=['collapse']` in the Inline class.

As nested inlines can be even longer than regular inlines, it would be really nice to have this feature in django-nested-admin too.

I tried to make it work (patched django with the commit above, and made the same changes to nested-admin's stacked and tabular templates). It's almost ok, but it breaks the ability to order the rows by drag&drop for tabular inlines nested in stacked inlines.

Thanks for the great work

items.title: Multiple inlines rendered for a single model when that model has another Many-to-Many relationship
items.body:
## models.py

The team model can be assigned with a generic relationship to another model.

``` python
class Team(models.Model):
    name = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    # Generic relationship
    content_type = models.ForeignKey(ContentType, on_delete=models.CASCADE)
    object_id = models.PositiveIntegerField()
    content_object = GenericForeignKey('content_type', 'object_id')

    class Meta:
        ordering = ['name']


class TeamRole(models.Model):
    role = models.ForeignKey(Role)
    team = models.ForeignKey(Team)
    members = models.ManyToManyField(User, blank=True)

    class Meta:
        ordering = ['team', 'role', 'members__first_name', 'members__last_name']

```
## admin.py

``` python

class TeamRoleInline(nested_admin.NestedTabularInline):
    model = TeamRole
    extra = 0
    filter_horizontal = ['members', ]

class TeamInline(nested_admin.NestedGenericStackedInline):
    model = Team
    extra = 0
    inlines = [TeamRoleInline, ]
```

However, when adding multiple members to a TeamRole, multiple inline rows are rendered for that team role:

![screenshot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2312145/16433051/12fffdd8-3d3d-11e6-99f8-853bd3ddb398.png)

In my serializer, to get around this issue:

``` python
class TeamListSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    roles = serializers.SerializerMethodField()

    class Meta:
        model = Team

    def get_roles(self, obj):
        return TeamRoleListSerializer(
            obj.teamrole_set.order_by('pk').distinct('pk'), many=True).data
```

items.title: save() prohibited to prevent data loss due to unsaved related object
items.body:
Hello!  First off, thanks for the great project.

Using:
django-1.9.7
django-nested-admin-3.0.5 
django-grappelli-2.8.1

And with a quick contrived example app that looks like the following:

```
# models.py
class Main(models.Model):
    text = models.CharField(max_length=255, blank=True, null=True)

class Level1(models.Model):
    main = models.ForeignKey(Main)

class Level2(models.Model):
    level_1 = models.ForeignKey(Level1)
    text = models.CharField(max_length=255, blank=True, null=True)

# admin.py
class Level2InlineAdmin (nested_admin.NestedTabularInline):
  model = Level2
  extra = 0

class Level1InlineAdmin (nested_admin.NestedStackedInline):
  model = Level1
  extra = 0
  inlines = [ Level2InlineAdmin, ]

class MainAdmin (nested_admin.NestedModelAdmin):
  inlines = [ Level1InlineAdmin, ]

admin.site.register(Main, MainAdmin)
admin.site.register(Level1)
admin.site.register(Level2)
```

I get the error in the title the first time I attempt to create a `Main` item and add a `Level2` item.

It seems like there's a problem saving the intermediate `Level1` model if the admin form didn't detect changes to that model specifically.  Unfortunately I'm relatively new to Django, and am uncertain where to look for this kind of fix.

Please let me know if there's any more detail I can provide, or if I just have a fundamental misunderstanding of something :)

items.title: Decimal values resetting
items.body:
I have a simple model of an assessment and an assessment version.  One assessment can have multiple versions.  When I use the nested admin module the version control field is being reset on the UI to incrementing values starting at zero.  I can set the values through the django shell so the model and DB appear to be set up correctly.  I swapped back to the standard django admin and the values were stored and displayed as expected.  Any idea what could be causing the issue? 

DJANGO = 1.8 
django-nested-admin = 3.0.2

``` python
# Model
class Assessments(models.Model): 
    """Assessments Table"""
    Assessment = models.CharField(max_length=100, blank=False)

    def __unicode__(self):
        return self.Assessment 

    class Meta: 
        ordering = ['Assessment']
        verbose_name_plural = "Assessments"

class AssessmentVersion(models.Model): 
    """Assessment Versions Table"""
    Assessment = models.ForeignKey('Assessments')
    Version = models.DecimalField(max_digits=4, decimal_places=2)
    Description = models.CharField(max_length=500, blank=True)

    def __unicode__(self): 
        return "{0} : {1}".format(self.Assessment, unicode(self.Version))

    class Meta: 
        ordering = ['Assessment','Version']
        verbose_name_plural="Assessment Version"


# Admin (swap for standard admin) 
class AssessmentVersionInLine(nested_admin.NestedStackedInline):
    model = AssessmentVersion 
    sortable_field_name = 'Version'
    extra = 0

class AssessmentAdmin(nested_admin.NestedModelAdmin):
    model = Assessments
    fieldsets = [
        (None,               {'fields': ['Assessment']}),
    ]
    sortable_field_name = 'Assessment'
    inlines = [AssessmentVersionInLine]
    extra = 0
```

items.title: DateTime shortcuts don't work when adding another inline
items.body:
I already shared this issue in the last one, but because it is a separate issue, I'll add it here.  When adding a new inline, if it has a DateTime field, the shortcuts don't work, instead just jumping you up to the top of the page.
